newsitem.title: USA: IBM says has approval on encryption exports.
newsitem.headline: IBM says has approval on encryption exports.

text.p: International Business Machines Corp received permission last week from the U.S. Commerce Department to export more powerful encryption software, a company official said.
IBM is the fourth company to acknowledge receiving a license under a new Clinton administration policy that took effect Jan 1.

Encryption programs, which use mathematical formulas to scramble information and render it unreadable without a password or software "key," have become an increasingly important part of online commerce and global communications.

The security provided by encryption, whether for a business' electronic mail or a consumer's credit card number sent over the Internet, is largely a function of the length of the software "key" measured in the smallest unit of computer data, a one or zero known as a bit.
Each additional bit doubles the number of possible key combinations.
Under previous export laws, U.S. companies could export only 40-bit programs. Under the new policy, IBM and a few others have been allowed to export 56-bit programs.

A California graduate student last month cracked a message encoded with 40-bit encryption in under four hours using a network of computer workstations. A message encoded with 56-bits would be more than 65,000 times harder to crack.
U.S. export restrictions are intended to keep difficult to crack coding capabilities out of the hands of criminals and terrorists.

So in return for allowing companies to export 56-bit programs, the government extracted a promise from the companies to include within two years features allowing the government to crack the codes by recovering the "keys."
When the two years are up, IBM and the others will have to incorporate key recovery features into any program for export that uses more than 40 bit long keys.
Digital Equipment Corp, Trusted Information Systems Inc, and Cylink Corp have also said they received 56-bit export licenses.

Many companies and civil libertarians have attacked the mandatory key recovery plan as unworkable and an invasion of privacy. A coalition of 16 trade groups sent President Bill Clinton a letter last week blasting the policy.
